title: 112_hr6364
content:
The Act may be cited as the "World War I Centennial Commission Act" and includes a table of contents. The World War I Centennial Commission Act includes findings about the centennial of World War I and the significance of American involvement in the war. The United States played a significant role in World War I, with over 4 million men and women serving in uniform. This war shaped the world and the lives of millions of people, leading to 375,000 American casualties. The centennial of World War I provides an opportunity for Americans to learn about and honor the sacrifices of their predecessors. Commemorative programs and sites in the United States allow people to learn about World War I history, US involvement, and its effects on the 20th century. Definitions in the Act include America's National World War I Museum and the Centennial Commission. The World War I Centennial Commission was established by the Act, with membership composed of 12 members appointed by various leaders in Congress. A veterans service organization is defined as any group recognized by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for representing veterans. The World War I Centennial Commission consists of 12 members appointed by different leaders, including the majority and minority leaders of the Senate, the President, veterans service organizations, and other associations. Members must be appointed within 60 days of the Act's establishment. The Centennial Commission, consisting of 12 members appointed by various leaders, must be appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Each member serves for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled as per original appointment method. Meetings are held within 30 days of all appointments at the America's National World War I Museum, subsequent meetings are called by the Chair as needed. The Centennial Commission, with 12 members appointed by leaders, meets at least once a year at the America's National World War I Museum. Seven members form a quorum, and the Commission selects a Chair and Vice Chair. Their duties include planning and executing programs to commemorate World War I. The Centennial Commission was established to encourage organizations and governments to participate in activities commemorating World War I, coordinate nationwide events, serve as an information hub, and make recommendations to Congress and the President. The Commission is required to submit periodic reports on its activities and plans. The Centennial Commission is mandated to submit recommendations for commemorating the centennial of World War I to Congress and the President within 2 years of the enactment of the Act. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and authorize members or agents to take necessary actions. The Centennial Commission can obtain necessary information from federal agencies and receive administrative support services from the General Services Administration. The Commission is authorized to procure supplies, services, and property. The Centennial Commission is authorized to procure supplies, services, and property, make contracts, and use postal services. They can also accept gifts, bequests, or devises to cover costs. Personnel matters, including compensation of members, are also addressed. The Centennial Commission members serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Chair appoints an executive director and staff, with the authority to set their compensation. The Chair of the Centennial Commission cannot set compensation above a certain level for the executive director and staff. If space is available, they should work at the America's National World War I Museum building in Kansas City. Federal departments can detail employees upon request. The Centennial Commission can detail employees from Federal departments to assist in its duties. The Chair can procure temporary services and funds from gifts, bequests, and devises. The Commission will terminate 30 days after completing activities honoring the centennial observation of World War I. The Centennial Commission can utilize employees from Federal departments and procure temporary services and funds from gifts, bequests, and devises. The Commission's activities honoring the centennial observation of World War I must be completed by July 28, 2019. The Federal Advisory Committee Act applies to the Commission's activities, with an exception to Section 14(a)(2). No Federal funds can be used to carry out this Act.
